titleStmt.title: Shakespeare, William, 1564-1616 : : The two gentlemen of Verona (1623) a machine-readable transcription of the 1623 Folio

publicationStmt.publisher: William Shakespeare, 1564-1616 (1564-1616) The two gentlemen of Verona [in, Mr. William Shakespeares Comedies, Histories, & Tragedies. Published according to the True Originall Copies] London Printed by Isaac Iaggard, and Ed. Blount 1623

sourceDesc.p:
Play details
The two gentlemen of Verona. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1623. Date first performed: 1593-1594?
Electronic text obtained Oxford, 1991, checked against Norton facsimile First Folio edition edited by Charlton Hinman

editorialDecl.p: analysis - elected part-of-sp suffixes as entities

encodingDesc.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Valentine Protheus Speed Julia Lucetta Antonio Panthino Silvia Launce Thurio Duke Host Song Eglamore Outlaw 1 Outlaw 2 Outlaw 3

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Cease to persuade, my loving Protheus;
Home-keeping youth, have ever homely wits,
Were it not affection chains thy tender days
To the sweet glances of thy honoured Love,
I rather would entreat thy company,
To see the wonders of the world abroad,
Than (living dully sluggardised at home)
Wear out thy youth with shapeless idleness.
But since thou lovest; love still, and thrive therein,
Even as I would, when I to love begin.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Wilt thou be gone? Sweet Valentine adieu,
Think on thy Protheus, when thou (happily) seest
Some rare note-worthy object in thy travail.
Wish me partaker in thy happiness,
When thou dost meet good hap; and in thy danger,
(If ever danger do environ thee)
Commend thy grievance to my holy prayers,
For I will be thy beadsman, Valentine.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: And on a love-book pray for my success?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Upon some book I love, I will pray for thee.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: That is on some shallow Story of deep love,
How young Leander crossed the Hellespont.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: That is a deep Story, of a deeper love,
For he was more than overshoes in love.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: It is true; for you are overboots in love,
And yet you never swum the Hellespont.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Over the Boots? nay give me not the Boots.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: No, I will not; for it boots thee not.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: To be in love; where scorn is bought with groans:
Coy looks, with heart-sore sighs: one fading moments mirth,
With twenty watchful, weary, tedious nights;
If happily won, perhaps a hapless gain;
If lost, why then a grievous labour won;
How ever: but a folly bought with wit,
Or else a wit, by folly vanquished.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: So, by your circumstance, you call me fool.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: So, by your circumstance, I fear you will prove.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: It is Love you cavil at, I am not Love.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Love is your master, for he masters you;
And he that is so yoked by a fool,
Methinks should not be chronicled for wise.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Yet Writers say; as in the sweetest Bud,
The eating Canker dwells; so eating Love
Inhabits in the finest wits of all.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: And Writers say; as the most forward Bud
Is eaten by the Canker ere it blow,
Even so by Love, the young, and tender wit
Is turned to folly, blasting in the Bud,
Loosing his verdure, even in the prime,
And all the fair effects of future hopes.
But wherefore waste I time to counsel thee
That art a votary to fond desire?
Once more adieu: my Father at the Road
Expects my coming, there to see me shipped.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: And thither will I bring thee Valentine.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Sweet Protheus, no: Now let us take our leave:
To Milan let me hear from thee by Letters
Of thy success in love; and what news else
Betideth here in absence of thy Friend:
And I likewise will visit thee with mine.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: All happiness bechance to thee in Milan.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: As much to you at home: and so farewell.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: He after Honour hunts, I after Love;
He leaves his friends, to dignify them more;
I love myself, my friends, and all for love:
Thou Iulia, thou hast metamorphosed me:
Made me neglect my Studies, loose my time;
War with good counsel; set the world at nought;
Made Wit with musing, weak; heartsick with thought.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: Sir Protheus: save you: saw you my Master?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: But now he parted hence to embark for Milan.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: Twenty to one then, he is shipped already,
And I have played the Sheep in loosing him.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Indeed a Sheep doth very often stray,
And if the shepherd be awhile away.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
You conclude that my Master is a shepherd then,
and I Sheep?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I do.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
Why then my horns are his horns, whether I
wake or sleep.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: A silly answer, and fitting well a Sheep.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: This proves me still a Sheep.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: True: and thy Master a shepherd.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: Nay, that I can deny by a circumstance.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: It shall go hard but I will prove it by another.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
The shepherd seeks the Sheep, and not the
Sheep the shepherd; but I seek my Master, and my
Master seeks not me: therefore I am no Sheep.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p:
The Sheep for fodder follow the shepherd,
the shepherd for food follows not the Sheep: thou
for wages followest thy Master, thy Master for wages
follows not thee: therefore thou art a Sheep.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: Such another proof will make me cry baa.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p:
But dost thou hear: gavest thou my Letter
to Iulia?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
Aye Sir: I (a lost-Mutton) gave your Letter to her
(a laced mutton) and she (a laced mutton) gave me (a
lost-Mutton) nothing for my labour.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p:
Here is too small a Pasture for such store of
Muttons.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
If the ground be overcharged, you were best
stick her.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p:
Nay, in that you are astray: it were best pound
you.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
Nay Sir, less then a pound shall serve me for carrying
your Letter.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: You mistake; I mean the pound, a Pinfold.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: From a pound to a pin? fold it over and over,
It is threefold too little for carrying a letter to your lover

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: But what said she?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: Aye.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Noddy, why that is noddy.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: You mistook Sir: I say she did nod;
And you ask me if she did nod, and Aye say I.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: And that set together is noddy.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
Now you have taken the pains to set it together,
take it for your pains.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: No, no, you shall have it for bearing the letter.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: Well, I perceive I must be fain to bear with you.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Why Sir, how do you bear with me?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: Marry Sir, the letter very orderly,
Having nothing but the word noddy for my pains.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Beshrew me, but you have a quick wit.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: And yet it cannot overtake your slow purse.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p:
Come, come, open the matter in brief; what
said she.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
Open your purse, that the money, and the matter
may be both at once delivered.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Well Sir: here is for your pains: what said she?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: Truly Sir, I think you will hardly win her.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Why? couldst thou perceive so much from her?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: Sir, I could perceive nothing at all from her;
No, not so much as a ducat for delivering your letter:
And being so hard to me, that brought your mind;
I fear she will prove as hard to you in telling your mind.
Give her no token but stones, for she is as hard as steel.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: What said she, nothing?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: No, not so much as take this for thy pains:
To testify your bounty, I thank you, you have testerned me;
sp.p:
In requital whereof, henceforth, carry your letters yourself;
And so Sir, I will commend you to my Master.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Go, go, be gone, to save your Ship from wrack,
Which cannot perish having thee aboard,
Being destined to a drier death on shore:
I must go send some better Messenger,
I fear my Iulia would not deign my lines,
Receiving them from such a worthless post.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: But say Lucetta (now we are alone)
Wouldst thou then counsel me to fall in love?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Aye Madam, so you stumble not unheedfully.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Of all the fair resort of Gentlemen,
That every day with parley encounter me,
In thy opinion which is worthiest love?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Please you repeat their names, I will show my mind,
According to my shallow simple skill.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: What thinkst thou of the fair sir Eglamoure?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: As of a Knight, well-spoken, neat, and fine;
But were I you, he never should be mine.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: What thinkst thou of the rich Mercatio?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Well of his wealth; but of himself, so, so.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: What thinkst thou of the gentle Protheus?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Lord, Lord: to see what folly reigns in us.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: How now? what means this passion at his name?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Pardon dear Madam, it is a passing shame,
That I (unworthy body as I am)
Should censure thus on lovely Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Why not on Protheus, as of all the rest?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Then thus: of many good, I think him best.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Your reason?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I have no other but a woman's reason:
I think him so, because I think him so.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: And wouldst thou have me cast my love on him?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Aye: if you thought your love not cast away.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Why he, of all the rest, hath never moved me.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Yet he, of all the rest, I think best loves ye.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: His little speaking, shows his love but small.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Fire that is closest kept, burns most of all.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: They do not love, that do not show their love.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: O, they love least, that let men know their love.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I would I knew his mind.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Peruse this paper Madam.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: To Iulia: say, from whom?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: That the Contents will show.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Say, say: who gave it thee?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Sir Valentines page: and sent I think from Protheus;
He would have given it you, but I being in the way,
Did in your name receive it: pardon the fault I pray.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Now (by my modesty) a goodly Broker:
Dare you presume to harbour wanton lines?
To whisper, and conspire against my youth?
Now trust me, it is an office of great worth,
And you an officer fit for the place:
There: take the paper: see it be returned,
Or else return no more into my sight.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: To plead for love, deserves more fee, than hate.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Will ye be gone?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: That you may ruminate.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: And yet I would I had overlooked the Letter;
It were a shame to call her back again,
And pray her to a fault, for which I chid her.
What fool is she, that knows I am a Maid,
And would not force the letter to my view?
Since Maids, in modesty, say no, to that,
Which they would have the profferer construe, Aye.
Fie, fie: how wayward is this foolish love;
That (like a testy Babe) will scratch the Nurse,
And presently, all humbled kiss the Rod?
How churlishly, I chid Lucetta hence,
When willingly, I would have had her here?
How angrily I taught my brow to frown,
When inward joy enforced my heart to smile?
My penance is, to call Lucetta back
And ask remission, for my folly past.
What ho: Lucetta.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: What would your Ladyship?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Is it near dinner time?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I would it were,
That you might kill your stomach on your meat,
And not upon your Maid.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: What is it that you
Took up so gingerly?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Why didst thou stoop then?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: To take a paper up, that I let fall.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: And is that paper nothing?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Nothing concerning me.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Then let it lie, for those that it concerns.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Madam, it will not lie where it concerns,
Unless it have a false Interpreter.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Some love of yours, hath writ to you in rhyme.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: That I might sing it (Madam) to a tune:
Give me a Note, your Ladyship can set

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: As little by such toys, as may be possible:
Best sing it to the tune of Light O, Love.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: It is too heavy for so light a tune.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Heavy? belike it hath some burden then?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Aye: and melodious were it, would you sing it,

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: And why not you?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I cannot reach so high.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Let us see your Song:
How now Minion?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Keep tune there still; so you will sing it out:
And yet methinks I do not like this tune.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: You do not?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: No (Madam) it is too sharp.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: You (Minion) are too saucy.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Nay, now you are too flat;
And mar the concord, with too harsh a descant:
There wanteth but a Mean to fill your Song.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: The mean is drowned with you unruly base.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Indeed I bid the base for Protheus.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: This babble shall not henceforth trouble me;
Here is a coil with protestation:
Go, get you gone: and let the papers lie:
You would be fingering them, to anger me.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: She makes it strange, but she would be best pleased
To be so angered with another Letter.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Nay, would I were so angered with the same:
O hateful hands, to tear such loving words;
Injurious Wasps, to feed on such sweet honey,
And kill the Bees that yield it, with your stings;
I will kiss each several paper, for amends:
Look, here is writ, kind Iulia: unkind Iulia,
As in revenge of thy ingratitude,
I throw thy name against the bruising stones,
Trampling contemptuously on thy disdain.
And here is writ, Love wounded Protheus.
Poor wounded name: my bosom, as a bed,
Shall lodge thee till thy wound be thoroughly healed;
And thus I search it with a sovereign kiss.
But twice, or thrice, was Protheus written down:
Be calm (good wind) blow not a word away,
Till I have found each letter, in the Letter,
Except mine own name: That, some whirlwind bear
Unto a ragged, fearful, hanging Rock,
And throw it thence into the raging Sea.
Lo, here in one line is his name twice writ:
To the sweet Iulia: that I will tear away:
And yet I will not, sith so prettily
He couples it, to his complaining Names;
Thus will I fold them, one upon another;
Now kiss, embrace, contend, do what you will.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Madam: dinner is ready: and your father stays.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Well, let us go.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: What, shall these papers lie, like Telltales here?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: If you respect them; best to take them up.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Nay, I was taken up, for laying them down.
Yet here they shall not lie, for catching cold.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I see you have a months mind to them.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Aye (Madam) you may say what sights you see;
I see things too, although you judge I wink.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Come, come, will it please you go.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Tell me Panthino, what sad talk was that,
Wherewith my brother held you in the Cloister?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: It was of his Nephew Protheus, your Son.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why? what of him?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: He wondered that your Lordship
Would suffer him, to spend his youth at home,
While other men, of slender reputation
Put forth their Sons, to seek preferment out.
Some to the wars, to try their fortune there;
Some, to discover Islands far away:
Some, to the studious Universities;
For any, or for all these exercises,
He said, that Protheus, your son, was meet;
And did request me, to importune you
To let him spend his time no more at home;
Which would be great impeachment to his age,
In having known no travail in his youth.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nor needst thou much importune me to that
Whereon, this month I have been hammering.
I have considered well, his loss of time,
And how he cannot be a perfect man,
Not being tried, and tutored in the world:
Experience is by industry achieved,
And perfected by the swift course of time:
Then tell me, whether were I best to send him?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I think your Lordship is not ignorant
How his companion, youthful Valentine,
Attends the Emperor in his royal Court.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I know it well.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: It were good, I think, your Lordship sent him thither,
There shall he practise Tilts, and Tournaments;
Hear sweet discourse, converse with Noblemen,
And be in eye of every Exercise
Worthy his youth, and nobleness of birth.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I like thy counsel: well hast thou advised:
And that thou mayst perceive how well I like it,
The execution of it shall make known;
Even with the speediest expedition,
I will dispatch him to the Emperors Court.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Tomorrow, may it please you, Don Alphonso,
With other Gentlemen of good esteem
Are journeying, to salute the Emperor,
And to commend their service to his will.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Good company: with them shall Protheus go:
And in good time: now will we break with him.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Sweet Love, sweet lines, sweet life,
Here is her hand, the agent of her heart;
Here is her oath for love, her honours pawn;
O that our Fathers would applaud our loves
To seal our happiness with their consents.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: O heavenly Iulia.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How now? What Letter are you reading there?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: May it please your Lordship, it is a word or two
Of commendations sent from Valentine;
Delivered by a friend, that came from him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Lend me the Letter: Let me see what news.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: There is no news (my Lord) but that he writes
How happily he lives, how well-beloved,
And daily graced by the Emperor;
Wishing me with him, partner of his fortune.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And how stand you affected to his wish?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: As one relying on your Lordships will,
And not depending on his friendly wish.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My will is something sorted with his wish:
Muse not that I thus suddenly proceed;
For what I will, I will, and there an end:
I am resolved, that thou shalt spend some time
With Valentinus, in the Emperors Court:
What maintenance he from his friends receives,
Like exhibition thou shalt have from me,
Tomorrow be in readiness, to go,
Excuse it not: for I am peremptory.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: My Lord I cannot be so soon provided,
Please you deliberate a day or two.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Look what thou wantest shall be sent after thee:
No more of stay: tomorrow thou must go;
Come on Panthino; you shall be employed,
To hasten on his Expedition.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Thus have I shunned the fire, for fear of burning,
And drenched me in the sea, where I am drowned.
I feared to show my Father Iulias Letter,
Lest he should take exceptions to my love,
And with the vantage of mine own excuse
Hath he excepted most against my love.
O, how this spring of love resembleth
The uncertain glory of an April day,
Which now shows all the beauty of the Sun,
And by and by a cloud takes all away.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Sir Protheus, your Fathers calls for you,
He is in haste, therefore I pray you go.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Why this it is: my heart accords thereto,
And yet a thousand times it answers no.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Sir, your Glove.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.l: Not mine: my Gloves are on.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: Why then this may be yours: for this is but one.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Ha? Let me see: Aye, give it me, it is mine:
Sweet Ornament, that decks a thing divine,
Ah Siluia, Siluia.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Madam Siluia: Madam Siluia.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: How now Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: She is not within hearing Sir.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Why sir, who bad you call her?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Your worship sir, or else I mistook.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Well: you will still be too forward.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: And yet I was last chidden for being too slow.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Go to, sir, tell me: do you know Madam Siluia?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: She that your worship loves?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Why, how know you that I am in love?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Marry by these special marks: first, you have
learned (like Sir Protheus) to wreath your Arms like a
Malcontent: to relish a Love-song, like a Robin- red-breast:
to walk alone like one that had the pestilence:
to sigh, like a Schoolboy that had lost his A.B.C. to
weep like a young wench that had buried her Grandam:
to; fast, like one that takes diet: to watch, like one that
fears robbing: to speak pulling, like a beggar at Hallowmas:
You were wont, when you laughed, to crow
like a cock; when you walked, to walk like one of the
Lions: when you fasted, it was presently after dinner:
when you looked sadly, it was for want of money: And
now you are Metamorphosed with a Mistress, that when I
look on you, I can hardly think you my Master.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Are all these things perceived in me?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: They are all perceived without ye.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Without me? they cannot.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Without you? nay, that is certain: for without
you were so simple, none else would: but you are
so without these follies, that these follies are within you,
and shine through you like the water in an Urinal: that
not an eye that sees you, but is a Physician to comment
on your Malady.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: But tell me: dost thou know my Lady Siluia?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: She that you gaze on so, as she sits at supper?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Hast thou observed that? even she I mean.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Why sir, I know her not.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.p:
Dost thou know her by my gazing on her, and
yet knowest her not?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Is she not hard-favoured, sir?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Not so fair (boy) as well favoured.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Sir, I know that well enough.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: What dost thou know?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: That she is not so fair, as (of you) well-favoured?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: I mean that her beauty is exquisite,
But her favour infinite.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
That is because the one is painted, and the other
out of all count.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: How painted? and how out of count?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Marry sir, so painted to make her fair, that no
man counts of her beauty.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: How esteemest thou me? I account of her beauty.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: You never saw her since she was deformed.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: How long hath she been deformed?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Ever since you loved her.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: I have loved her ever since I saw her,
And still I see her beautiful.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: If you love her, you cannot see her.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Because Love is blind: O that you had mine
eyes, or your own eyes had the lights they were wont
to have, when you chid at Sir Protheus, for going ungartered.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: What should I see then?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Your own present folly, and her passing deformity:
for he being in love, could not see to garter
his hose; and you, being in love, cannot see to put on
your hose.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.p:
Belike (boy) then you are in love, for last morning
You could not see to wipe my shoes.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
True sir: I was in love with my bed, I thank
you, you swinged me for my love, which makes me the
bolder to chide you, for yours.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: In conclusion, I stand affected to her.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
I would you were set, so your affection would
cease.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Last night she enjoined me,
To write some lines to one she loves.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: And have you?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: I have.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Are they not lamely writ?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: No (Boy) but as well as I can do them:
Peace, here she comes.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: O excellent motion; o exceeding Puppet:
Now will he interpret to her.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Madam and Mistress, a thousand good-morrows.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
O, give ye good even: here is a million of
manners.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Sir Valentine, and servant, to you two thousand.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: He should give her interest: and she gives it him.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: As you enjoined me; I have writ your Letter
Unto the secret, nameless friend of yours:
Which I was much unwilling to proceed in,
But for my duty to your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I thank you (gentle Servant) it is very Clerkly done.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Now trust me (Madam) it came hardly-off:
For being ignorant to whom it goes,
I writ at random, very doubtfully.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Perchance you think too much of so much pains?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: No (Madam) so it steed you, I will write
(Please you command) a thousand times as much:
And yet ~~

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: A pretty period: well: I guess the sequel;
And yet I will not name it: and yet I care not.
And yet, take this again: and yet I thank you:
Meaning henceforth to trouble you no more.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: And yet you will: and yet, another yet.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: What means your Ladyship?
Do you not like it?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Yes, yes: the lines are very quaintly writ,
But (since unwillingly) take them again.
Nay, take them.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Madam, they are for you.

sp.speaker: Silu.
sp.l: Aye, Aye: you writ them Sir, at my request,
But I will none of them: they are for you:
I would have had them writ more movingly:

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Please you, I will write your Ladyship another.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: And when it is writ: for my sake read it over,
And if it please you, so: if not: why so:

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: If it please me, (Madam?) what then?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Why if it please you, take it for your labour;
And so good-morrow Servant.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: O Jest unseen: inscrutable: invisible,
As a nose on a man's face, or a Weathercock on a steeple:
My Master sues to her: and she hath taught her Suitor,
He being her Pupil, to become her Tutor.
O excellent devise, was there ever heard a better?
That my master being scribe,
To himself should write the Letter?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: How now Sir?
What are you reasoning with yourself?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Nay: I was riming: it is you that have the reason.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: To do what?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: To be a Spokesman from Madam Siluia.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: To whom?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: To yourself: why, she woes you by a figure.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: What figure?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: By a Letter, I should say.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Why she hath not writ to me?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: What need she,
When she hath made you write to yourself?
Why, do you not perceive the jest?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: No, believe me.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: No believing you indeed sir:
But did you perceive her earnest?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: She gave me none, except an angry word.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Why she hath given you a Letter.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: That is the Letter I writ to her friend.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: And that letter hath she delivered, and there an end.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: I would it were no worse.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: I will warrant you, it is as well:
For often have you writ to her: and she in modesty,
Or else for want of idle time, could not again reply,
Or fearing else some messenger, that might her mind discover
Herself hath taught her Love himself, to write unto her lover.
All this I speak in print, for in print I found it.
Why muse you sir, it is dinner time.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: I have dined.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Aye, but hearken sir: though the Chameleon Love
can feed on the air, I am one that am nourished by my
victuals; and would fain have meat: o be not like
your Mistress, be moved, be moved.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Have patience, gentle Iulia:

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I must where is no remedy.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: When possibly I can, I will return.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: If you turn not: you will return the sooner:
Keep this remembrance for thy Iulia's sake.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Why then we will make exchange;
Here, take you this.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: And seal the bargain with a holy kiss.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Here is my hand, for my true constancy:
And when that hour overslips me in the day,
Wherein I sigh not (Iulia) for thy sake,
The next ensuing hour, some foul mischance
Torment me for my Loves forgetfulness:
My father stays my coming: answer not:
The tide is now; nay, not thy tide of tears,
That tide will stay me longer than I should,
Iulia, farewell: what, gone without a word?
Aye, so true love should do: it cannot speak,
For truth hath better deeds, than words to grace it.

sp.speaker: Panth.
sp.l: Sir Protheus: you are staid for.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Go: I come, I come:
Alas, this parting strikes poor Lovers dumb.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
Nay, it will be this hour ere I have done
weeping: all the kind of the Lances, have this very
fault: I have received my proportion, like the prodigious
Son, and am going with Sir Protheus to the Imperials
Court: I think Crab my dog, be the sourest natured
dog that lives: My Mother weeping: my Father
wailing: my Sister crying: our Maid howling: our
Cat wringing her hands, and all our house in a great
perplexity, yet did not this cruel-hearted Cur shed
one tear: he is a stone, a very pebble stone, and has no
more pity in him than a dog: a Jew would have wept
to have seen our parting: why my Grandam having
no eyes, look you, wept herself blind at my parting:
nay, I will show you the manner of it. This shoe is my father:
no, this left shoe is my father; no, no, this left
shoe is my mother: nay, that cannot be so neither:
yes; it is so, it is so: it hath the worser sole: this shoe
with the hole in it, is my mother: and this my father:
a vengeance on it, there it is: Now sir, this staff is my sister:
for, look you, she is as white as a lily, and as
small as a wand: this hat is Nan our maid: I am the
dog: no, the dog is himself, and I am the dog:
o, the dog is me, and I am myself: Aye; so, so: now
come I to my Father; Father, your blessing: now
should not the shoe speak a word for weeping:
now should I kiss my Father; well, he weeps on:
Now come I to my Mother: O that she could speak
now, like a would-woman: well, I kiss her: why
there it is; here is my mothers breath up and down:
Now come I to my sister; mark the moan she makes:
now the dog all this while sheds not a tear: nor
speaks a word: but see how I lay the dust with my
tears.

sp.speaker: Panth.
sp.p:
Lance, away, away: aboard: thy Master is
shipped, and thou art to post after with oars; what is the
matter? why weepest thou man? away ass, you will loose
the Tide, if you tarry any longer.

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p:
It is no matter if the tide were lost, for it is the
unkindest Tide, that ever any man tide.

sp.speaker: Panth.
sp.p: What is the unkindest tide?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Why, he that is tide here, Crab my dog.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p:
Tut, man: I mean thou wilt loose the flood, and
in loosing the flood, loose thy voyage, and in loosing thy
voyage, loose thy Master, and in loosing thy Master,
loose thy service, and in loosing thy service: ~~ why
dost thou stop my mouth?

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p: For fear thou shouldest loose thy tongue.

sp.speaker: Panth.
sp.p: Where should I loose my tongue?

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p: In thy Tale.

sp.speaker: Panth.
sp.p: In thy Tail.

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p:
Loose the Tide, and the voyage, and the Master,
and the Service, and the tide: why man, if the River
were dry, I am able to fill it with my tears: if the wind
were down, I could drive the boat with my sighs.

sp.speaker: Panth.
sp.p:
Come: come away man, I was sent to call
thee.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Sir: call me what thou darest.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: Wilt thou go?

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p: Well, I will go.

div2.head: Scena Quarta.
div2.stage: Enter Valentine, Siluia, Thurio, Speed, Duke, Protheus.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Servant.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Mistress.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.l: Master, Sir Thurio frowns on you.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Aye Boy, it is for love.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.l: Not of you.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Of my Mistress then.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.l: It were good you knocked him.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Servant, you are sad.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Indeed, Madam, I seem so.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: Seem you that you are not?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Happily I do.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: So do Counterfeits.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: So do you.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: What seem I that I am not?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Wise.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: What instance of the contrary?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Your folly.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: And how quote you my folly?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: I quote it in your Jerkin.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: My Jerkin is a doublet.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Well then, I will double your folly.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: What, angry, Sir Thurio, do you change colour?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Give him leave, Madam, he is a kind of Chameleon.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p:
That hath more mind to feed on your blood,
than live in your air.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: You have said Sir.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: Aye Sir, and done too for this time.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: I know it well sir, you always end ere you begin.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: A fine volley of words, gentlemen, and quickly shot off

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: It is indeed, Madam, we thank the giver.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Who is that Servant?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Yourself (sweet Lady) for you gave the fire,
Sir Thurio borrows his wit from your Ladyships looks,
And spends what he borrows kindly in your company.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p:
Sir, if you spend word for word with me, I shall
make your wit bankrupt.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: I know it well sir: you have an Exchequer of words,
And I think, no other treasure to give your followers:
For it appears by their bare Liveries
That they live by your bare words.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: No more, gentlemen, no more:
Here comes my father.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Now, daughter Siluia, you are hard beset.
Sir Valentine, your father is in good health,
What say you to a Letter from your friends
Of much good news?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: My Lord, I will be thankful,
To any happy messenger from thence.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Know ye Don Antonio, your Countryman?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Aye, my good Lord, I know the Gentleman
To be of worth, and worthy estimation,
And not without desert so well reputed.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Hath he not a Son?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Aye, my good Lord, a Son, that well deserves
The honour, and regard of such a father.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: You know him well?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: I knew him as myself: for from our Infancy
We have conversed, and spent our hours together,
And though myself have been an idle Truant,
Omitting the sweet benefit of time
To cloth mine age with Angel-like perfection:
Yet hath Sir Protheus (for that is his name)
Made use, and fair advantage of his days:
His years but young, but his experience old:
His head unmellowed, but his Judgment ripe;
And in a word (for far behind his worth
Comes all the praises that I now bestow.)
He is complete in feature, and in mind,
With all good grace, to grace a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Beshrew me sir, but if he make this good
He is as worthy for an Empress love,
As meet to be an Emperors Councillor:
Well, Sir: this Gentleman is come to me
With Commendation from great Potentates,
And here he means to spend his time awhile,
I think it is no unwelcome news to you.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Should I have wished a thing, it had been he.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Welcome him then according to his worth:
Siluia, I speak to you, and you Sir Thurio,
For Valentine, I need not cite him to it,
I will send him hither to you presently.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: This is the Gentleman I told your Ladyship
Had come along with me, but that his Mistress
Did hold his eyes, locked in her Crystal looks.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Belike that now she hath enfranchised them
Upon some other pawn for fealty.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Nay sure, I think she holds them prisoners still.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Nay then he should be blind, and being blind
How could he see his way to seek out you?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Why Lady, Love hath twenty pair of eyes.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.l: They say that Love hath not an eye at all.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: To see such Lovers, Thurio, as yourself,
Upon a homely object, Love can wink.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Have done, have done: here comes the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Welcome, deer Protheus: Mistress, I beseech you
Confirm his welcome, with some special favour.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: His worth is warrant for his welcome hither,
If this be he you oft have wished to hear from.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Mistress, it is: sweet Lady, entertain him
To be my fellow servant to your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Too low a Mistress for so high a servant.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Not so, sweet Lady, but too mean a servant
To have a look of such a worthy a Mistress.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Leave off discourse of disability:
Sweet Lady, entertain him for your Servant.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: My duty will I boast of, nothing else.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: And duty never yet did want his meed.
Servant, you are welcome to a worthless Mistress.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I will die on him that says so but yourself.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: That you are welcome?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: That you are worthless.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.l: Madam, my Lord your father would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I wait upon his pleasure: Come Sir Thurio,
Go with me: once more, new Servant welcome;
I will leave you to confer of home affairs,
When you have done, we look to hear from you.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: We will both attend upon your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Now tell me: how do all from whence you came?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Your friends are well, and have them much commended.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: And how do yours?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I left them all in health.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: How does your Lady? and how thrives your love?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: My tales of Love were wont to weary you,
I know you joy not in a Love discourse.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Aye Protheus, but that life is altered now,
I have done penance for contemning Love,
Whose high imperious thoughts have punished me
With bitter fasts, with penitential groans,
With nightly tears, and daily heart-sore sighs,
For in revenge of my contempt of love,
Love hath chased sleep from my enthralled eyes,
And made them watchers of mine own hearts sorrow.
O gentle Protheus, Love is a mighty Lord,
And hath so humbled me, as I confess
There is no woe to his correction,
Nor to his Service, no such joy on earth:
Now, no discourse, except it be of love:
Now can I break my fast, dine, sup, and sleep,
Upon the very naked name of Love.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Enough; I read your fortune in your eye:
Was this the Idol, that you worship so?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Even She; and is she not a heavenly Saint?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: No; But she is an earthly Paragon.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Call her divine.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I will not flatter her.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: O flatter me: for Love delights in praises.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: When I was sick, you gave me bitter pills,
And I must minister the like to you.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Then speak the truth by her; if not divine,
Yet let her be a principality,
Sovereign to all the Creatures on the earth.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Except my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Sweet: except not any,
Except thou wilt except against my Love.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Have I not reason to prefer mine own?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: And I will help thee to prefer her too:
She shall be dignified with this high honour,
To bear my Ladies train, lest the base earth
Should from her vesture chance to steal a kiss,
And of so great a favour growing proud,
Disdain to root the summer swelling flower,
And make rough winter everlastingly.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Why Valentine, what Bragadisme is this?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Pardon me (Protheus) all I can is nothing,
To her, whose worth, make other worthies nothing;
She is alone.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Then let her alone.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Not for the world: why man, she is mine own,
And I as rich in having such a Jewel
As twenty Seas, if all their sand were pearl,
The water, Nectar, and the Rocks pure gold.
Forgive me, that I do not dream on thee,
Because thou seest me dote upon my love:
My foolish Rival that her Father likes
(only for his possessions are so huge)
Is gone with her along, and I must after,
For Love (thou knowest is full of jealousy.)

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: But she loves you?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Aye, and we are betrothed: nay more, our marriage hour,
With all the cunning manner of our flight
Determined of: how I must climb her window,
The Ladder made of Cords, and all the means
Plotted, and agreed on for my happiness.
Good Protheus go with me to my chamber,
In these affairs to aid me with thy counsel.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Go on before: I shall enquire you forth:
I must unto the Road, to disembark
Some necessaries, that I needs must use,
And then I will presently attend you.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Will you make haste?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I will.
Even as one heat, another heat expels,
Or as one nail, by strength drives out another.
So the remembrance of my former Love
Is by a newer object quite forgotten,
It is mine, or Valentines praise?
Her true perfection, or my false transgression?
That makes me reasonless, to reason thus?
She is fair: and so is Iulia that I love,
(That I did love, for now my love is thawed,
Which like a waxen Image against a fire
Bears no impression of the thing it was.)
Methinks my zeal to Valentine is cold,
And that I love him not as I was wont:
O, but I love his Lady too-too much,
And that is the reason I love him so little.
How shall I dote on her with more advice,
That thus without advice begin to love her?
It is but her picture I have yet beheld,
And that hath dazzled my reasons light:
But when I look on her perfections,
There is no reason, but I shall be blind.
If I can check my erring love, I will,
If not, to compass her I will use my skill.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Lance, by mine honesty welcome to Padua.

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p:
Forswear not thyself, sweet youth, for I am
not welcome. I reckon this always, that a man is never
undone till he be hanged, nor never welcome to a place,
till some certain shot be paid, and the Hostess say welcome.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Come on you mad-cap: I will to the Alehouse
with you presently; where, for one shot of five pence,
thou shalt have five thousand welcomes: But sirrah, how
did thy Master part with Madam Iulia?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p:
Marry after they closed in earnest, they parted
very fairly in jest.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p: But shall she marry him?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p: How then? shall he marry her?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: No, neither.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p: What, are they broken?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: No; they are both as whole as a fish.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p: Why then, how stands the matter with them?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p:
Marry thus, when it stands well with him, it
stands well with her.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p: What an ass art thou, I understand thee not.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p:
What a block art thou, that thou canst not?
My staff understands me?

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p: What thou sayst?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p:
Aye, and what I do too: look thee, I will but lean,
and my staff understands me.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p: It stands under thee indeed.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Why, stand under: and understand is all one.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.l: But tell me true, will it be a match?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p:
Ask my dog, if he say Aye, it will: if he say
no, it will: if he shake his tail, and say nothing, it
will.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p: The conclusion is then, that it will.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p:
Thou shalt never get such a secret from me, but
by a parable.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p:
It is well that I get it so: but Lance, how sayst
thou that my master is become a notable Lover?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I never knew him otherwise.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p: Then how?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p:
A notable Lubber: as thou reportest him to
be.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p: Why, thou whoreson Ass, thou mistakest me,

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p:
Why Fool, I meant not thee, I meant thy
Master.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p: I tell thee, my Master is become a hot Lover.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p:
Why, I tell thee, I care not, though he burn
himself in Love. If thou wilt go with me to the Alehouse:
if not, thou art an Hebrew, a Jew, and not worth
the name of a Christian.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p:
Because thou hast not so much charity in thee as
to go to the Ale with a Christian: Wilt thou go?

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p: At thy service.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: To leave my Iulia; shall I be forsworn?
To love fair Siluia; shall I be forsworn?
To wrong my friend, I shall be much forsworn.
And even that Power which gave me first my oath
Provokes me to this threefold perjury.
Love bad me swear, and Love bids me forswear;
O sweet-suggesting Love, if thou hast sinned,
Teach me (thy tempted subject) to excuse it.
At first I did adore a twinkling Star,
But now I worship a celestial Sun:
Unheedful vows may heedfully be broken,
And he wants wit, that wants resolved will,
To learn his wit, to exchange the bad for better;
Fie, fie, unreverend tongue, to call her bad,
Whose sovereignty so oft thou hast preferred,
With twenty thousand soul confirming oaths.
I cannot leave to love; and yet I do:
But there I leave to love, where I should love.
Iulia I loose, and Valentine I loose,
If I keep them, I needs must loose myself:
If I loose them, thus find I by their loss,
For Valentine, myself: for Iulia, Siluia.
I to myself am dearer than a friend,
For Love is still most precious in itself,
And Siluia (witness heaven that made her fair)
Shows Iulia but a swarthy Ethiope.
I will forget that Iulia is alive,
Remembering that my Love to her is dead.
And Valentine I will hold an Enemy,
Aiming at Siluia as a sweeter friend.
I cannot now prove constant to myself,
Without some treachery used to Valentine.
This night he meaneth with a Corded-ladder
To climb celestial Siluia's chamber window,
Myself in counsel his competitor.
Now presently I will give her father notice
Of their disguising and pretended flight:
Who (all enraged) will banish Valentine:
For Thurio he intends shall wed his daughter,
But Valentine being gone, I will quickly cross
By some sly trick, blunt Thurio's dull proceeding.
Love lend me wings, to make my purpose swift
As thou hast lent me wit, to plot this drift.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Counsel, Lucetta, gentle girl assist me,
And even in kind love, I do conjure thee,
Who art the Table wherein all my thoughts
Are visibly Charactered, and engraved,
To lesson me, and tell me some good mean
How with my honour I may undertake
A journey to my loving Protheus.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Alas, the way is wearisome and long.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: A true devoted Pilgrim is not weary
To measure Kingdoms with his feeble steps,
Much less shall she that hath Loves wings to fly,
And when the flight is made to one so dear,
Of such divine perfection as Sir Protheus.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Better forbear, till Protheus make return.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: O, knowest thou not, his looks are my souls food?
Pity the dearth that I have pined in,
By longing for that food so long a time.
Didst thou but know the inly touch of Love,
Thou wouldst as soon go kindle fire with snow
As seek to quench the fire of Love with words.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I do not seek to quench your Loves hot fire,
But qualify the fires extreme rage,
Lest it should burn above the bounds of reason.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: The more thou dammest it up, the more it burns:
The Current that with gentle murmur glides
(Thou knowest) being stopped, impatiently doth rage:
But when his fair course is not hindered,
He makes sweet music with the enamelled stones,
Giving a gentle kiss to every sedge
He overtaketh in his pilgrimage.
And so by many winding nooks he strays
With willing sport to the wild Ocean.
Then let me go, and hinder not my course:
I will be as patient as a gentle stream,
And make a pastime of each weary step,
Till the last step have brought me to my Love,
And there I will rest, as after much turmoil
A blessed soul doth in Elizium.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But in what habit will you go along?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Not like a woman, for I would prevent
The loose encounters of lascivious men:
Gentle Lucetta, fit me with such weeds
As may beseem some well reputed Page.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Why then your Ladyship must cut your hair.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: No girl, I will knit it up in silken strings,
With twenty odd conceited true-love knots:
To be fantastic, may become a youth
Of greater time than I shall show to be.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What fashion (Madam) shall I make your breeches?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: That fits as well, as tell me (good my Lord)
What compass will you wear your Farthingale?
Why even what fashion thou best likes (Lucetta.)

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You must needs have them with a codpiece Madam

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Out, out, (Lucetta) that will be ill-favoured.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: A round hose (Madam) now is not worth a pin
Unless you have a codpiece to stick pins on.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Lucetta, as thou lovest me let me have
What thou thinkst meet, and is most mannerly.
But tell me (wench) how will the world repute me
For undertaking so unstaid a journey?
I fear me it will make me scandalised.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: If you think so, then stay at home, and go not.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Nay, that I will not.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Then never dream on Infamy, but go:
If Protheus like your journey, when you come,
No matter who is displeased, when you are gone:
I fear me he will scarce be pleased with all.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: That is the least (Lucetta) of my fear:
A thousand oaths, an Ocean of his tears,
And instances of infinite of Love,
Warrant me welcome to my Protheus.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: All these are servants to deceitful men.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Base men, that use them to so base effect;
But truer stars did govern Protheus birth,
His words are bonds, his oaths are oracles,
His love sincere, his thoughts immaculate,
His tears, pure messengers, sent from his heart,
His heart, as far from fraud, as heaven from earth.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Pray heaven he prove so when you come to him.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Now, as thou lovest me, do him not that wrong,
To bear a hard opinion of his truth:
Only deserve my love, by loving him,
And presently go with me to my chamber
To take a note of what I stand in need of,
To furnish me upon my longing journey:
All that is mine I leave at thy dispose,
My goods, my Lands, my reputation,
Only, in lieu thereof, dispatch me hence:
Come; answer not: but to it presently,
I am impatient of my tarriance.

div2.head: Actus Tertius, Scena Prima.
div2.stage:
Enter Duke, Thurio, Protheus, Valentine,
Lance, Speed.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Sir Thurio, give us leave (I pray) awhile,
We have some secrets to confer about.
Now tell me Protheus, what is your will with me?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: My gracious Lord, that which I would discover,
The Law of friendship bids me to conceal,
But when I call to mind your gracious favours
Done to me (undeserving as I am)
My duty pricks me on to utter that
Which else, no worldly good should draw from me:
Know (worthy Prince) Sir Valentine my friend
This night intends to steal away your daughter:
Myself am one made privy to the plot.
I know you have determined to bestow her
On Thurio, whom your gentle daughter hates,
And should she thus be stolen away from you,
It would be much vexation to your age.
Thus (for my duties sake) I rather chose
To cross my friend in his intended drift,
Than (by concealing it) heap on your head
A pack of sorrows, which would press you down
(Being unprevented) to your timeless grave.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Protheus, I thank thee for thine honest care,
Which to requite, command me while I live.
This love of theirs, myself have often seen,
Happily when they have judged me fast asleep,
And oftentimes have purposed to forbid
Sir Valentine her company, and my Court.
But fearing lest my jealous aim might err,
And so (unworthily) disgrace the man
(A rashness that I ever yet have shunned)
I gave him gentle looks, thereby to find
That which thyself hast now disclosed to me.
And that thou mayst perceive my fear of this,
Knowing that tender youth is soon suggested,
I nightly lodge her in an upper Tower,
The key whereof, myself have ever kept:
And thence she cannot be conveyed away.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Know (noble Lord) they have devised a mean
How he her chamber-window will ascend,
And with a Corded-ladder fetch her down:
For which, the youthful Lover now is gone,
And this way comes he with it presently.
Where (if it please you) you may intercept him.
But (good my Lord) do it so cunningly
That my discovery be not aimed at:
For, love of you, not hate unto my friend,
Hath made me publisher of this pretence.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Upon mine Honour, he shall never know
That I had any light from thee of this.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Adieu, my Lord, Sir Valentine is coming.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Sir Valentine, whether away so fast?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Please it your Grace, there is a Messenger
That stays to bear my Letters to my friends,
And I am going to deliver them.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Be they of much import?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: The tenure of them doth but signify
My health, and happy being at your Court.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Nay then no matter: stay with me awhile,
I am to break with thee of some affairs
That touch me near: wherein thou must be secret.
It is not unknown to thee, that I have sought
To match my friend Sir Thurio, to my daughter.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: I know it well (my Lord) and sure the Match
Were rich and honourable: besides, the gentleman
Is full of Virtue, Bounty, Worth, and Qualities
Beseeming such a Wife, as your fair daughter:
Cannot your Grace win her to fancy him?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: No, trust me, She is peevish, sullen, froward,
Proud, disobedient, stubborn, lacking duty,
Neither regarding that she is my child,
Nor fearing me, as if I were her father:
And may I say to thee, this pride of hers
(Upon advice) hath drawn my love from her,
And where I thought the remnant of mine age
Should have been cherished by her child-like duty,
I now am full resolved to take a wife,
And turn her out, to who will take her in:
Then let her beauty be her wedding dower:
For me, and my possessions she esteems not.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: What would your Grace have me to do in this?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: There is a Lady in Verona here
Whom I affect: but she is nice, and coy,
And nought esteems my aged eloquence.
Now therefore would I have thee to my Tutor
(For long ago I have forgot to court,
Besides the fashion of the time is changed)
How, and which way I may bestow myself
To be regarded in her sun-bright eye.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Win her with gifts, if she respect not words,
Dumb Jewels often in their silent kind
More than quick words, do move a woman's mind.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: But she did scorn a present that I sent her,

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: A woman sometime scorns what best contents her.
Send her another: never give her over,
For scorn at first, makes after-love the more.
If she do frown, it is not in hate of you,
But rather to beget more love in you.
If she do chide, it is not to have you gone,
For why, the fools are mad, if left alone.
Take no repulse, whatever she doth say,
For, get you gone, she doth not mean away.
Flatter, and praise, commend, extol their graces:
Though never so black, say they have Angels faces,
That man that hath a tongue, I say is no man,
If with his tongue he cannot win a woman.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: But she I mean, is promised by her friends
Unto a youthful Gentleman of worth,
And kept severely from resort of men,
That no man hath access by day to her.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Why then I would resort to her by night.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Aye, but the doors be locked, and keys kept safe,
That no man hath recourse to her by night.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: What lets but one may enter at her window?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Her chamber is aloft, far from the ground,
And built so shelving, that one cannot climb it
Without apparent hazard of his life.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Why then a Ladder quaintly made of Cords
To cast up, with a pair of anchoring hooks,
Would serve to scale another heroes tower,
So bold Leander would adventure it.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Now as thou art a Gentleman of blood
Advise me, where I may have such a Ladder.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: When would you use it? pray sir, tell me that.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: This very night; for Love is like a child
That longs for everything that he can come by.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: By seven o'clock, I will get you such a Ladder.

sp.speaker: Duk
sp.l: But hark thee: I will go to her alone,
How shall I best convey the Ladder thither?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: It will be light (my Lord) that you may bear it
Under a cloak, that is of any length.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: A cloak as long as thine will serve the turn?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Aye my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Then let me see thy cloak,
I will get me one of such another length.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Why any cloak will serve the turn (my Lord)

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: How shall I fashion me to wear a cloak?
I pray thee let me feel thy cloak upon me.
What Letter is this same? what is here? to Siluia?
And here an Engine fit for my proceeding,
I will be so bold to break the seal for once.
My thoughts do harbour with my Siluia nightly,
And slaves they are to me, that send them flying.
O, could their Master come, and go as lightly,
Himself would lodge where (senseless) they are lying.
My Herald Thoughts, in thy pure bosom rest them,

l.emph: While I (their King) that thither them importune

sp.l: Do curse the grace, that with such grace hath blessed them,
Because myself do want my servants fortune.
I curse myself, for they are sent by me,
That they should harbour where their Lord should be.
What is here? Siluia, this night I will enfranchise thee.
It is so: and here is the Ladder for the purpose.
Why Phaeton (for thou art Merops son)
Wilt thou aspire to guide the heavenly Car?
And with thy daring folly burn the world?
Wilt thou reach stars, because they shine on thee?
Go base Intruder, overweening Slave,
Bestow thy fawning smiles on equal mates,
And think my patience, (more than thy desert)
Is privilege for thy departure hence.
Thank me for this, more than for all the favours
Which (all too much) I have bestowed on thee.
But if thou linger in my Territories
Longer than swiftest expedition
Will give thee time to leave our royal Court,
By heaven, my wrath shall far exceed the love
I ever bore my daughter, or thyself.
Be gone, I will not hear thy vain excuse,
But as thou lovest thy life, make speed from hence.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: And why not death, rather than living torment?
To die, is to be banished from myself,
And Siluia is myself: banished from her
Is self from self. A deadly banishment:
What light, is light, if Siluia be not seen?
What joy is joy, if Siluia be not by?
Unless it be to think that she is by
And feed upon the shadow of perfection.
Except I be by Siluia in the night,
There is no music in the Nightingale.
Unless I look on Siluia in the day,
There is no day for me to look upon.
She is my essence, and I leave to be;
If I be not by her fair influence
Fostered, illumined, cherished, kept alive.
I fly not death, to fly his deadly doom,
Tarry I here, I but attend on death,
But fly I hence, I fly away from life.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Run (boy) run, run, and seek him out.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: So-ho, So-ho ~~

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: What seest thou?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Him we go to find,
There is not a hair on his head, but it is a Valentine.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Valentine?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Who then? his Spirit?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Neither,

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Can nothing speak? Master, shall I strike?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Who wouldst thou strike?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Villain, forbear.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Why Sir, I will strike nothing: I pray you.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Sirrah, I say forbear: friend Valentine, a word.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: My ears are stopped, and cannot hear good news,
So much of bad already hath possessed them.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Then in dumb silence will I bury mine,
For they are harsh, untunable, and bad.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Is Siluia dead?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: No, Valentine.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: No Valentine indeed, for sacred Siluia,
Hath she forsworn me?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: No, Valentine.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: No Valentine, if Siluia have forsworn me.
What is your news?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Sir, there is a proclamation, that you are vanished.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: That thou art banished: o that is the news,
From hence, from Siluia, and from me thy friend.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: O, I have fed upon this woe already,
And now excess of it will make me surfeit.
Doth Siluia know that I am banished?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Aye, Aye: and she hath offered to the doom
(Which unreversed stands in effectual force)
A Sea of melting pearl, which some call tears;
Those at her fathers churlish feet she tendered,
With them upon her knees, her humble self,
Wringing her hands, whose whiteness so became them,
As if but now they waxed pale for woe:
But neither bended knees, pure hands held up,
Sad sighs, deep groans, nor silver shedding tears
Could penetrate her uncompassionate Sire;
But Valentine, if he be ta'en, must die.
Besides, her intercession chafed him so,
When she for thy repeal was suppliant,
That to close prison he commanded her,
With many bitter threats of biding there.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: No more: unless the next word that thou speakest
Have some malignant power upon my life:
If so: I pray thee breath it in mine ear,
As ending Anthem of my endless dolour.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Cease to lament for that thou canst not help,
And study help for that which thou lamentest,
Time is the Nurse, and breeder of all good;
Here, if thou stay, thou canst not see thy love:
Besides, thy staying will abridge thy life:
Hope is a lovers staff, walk hence with that
And manage it, against despairing thoughts:
Thy letters may be here, though thou art hence,
Which, being writ to me, shall be delivered
Even in the milk-white bosom of thy Love.
The time now serves not to expostulate,
Come, I will convey thee through the City-gate.
And ere I part with thee, confer at large
Of all that may concern thy Love affairs:
As thou lovest Siluia (though not for thyself)
Regard thy danger, and along with me.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: I pray thee Lance, and if thou seest my Boy
Bid him make haste, and meet me at the North-gate.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Go sirrah, find him out: Come Valentine.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: O my dear Siluia; hapless Valentine.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
I am but a fool, look you, and yet I have
the wit to think my Master is a kind of a knave: but
that is all one, if he be but one knave: He lives not now
that knows me to be in love, yet I am in love, but a
Teem of horse shall not pluck that from me: nor who
it is I love: and yet it is a woman; but what woman, I
will not tell myself: and yet it is a Milkmaid: yet it is
not a maid: for she hath had Gossips: yet it is a maid,
for she is her Masters maid, and serves for wages. She
hath more quality than a water-spaniel, which is
much in a bare Christian: Here is the Catalogue of her
Condition. Inprimis. She can fetch and carry: why
a horse can do no more; nay, a horse cannot fetch, but
only carry, therefore is she better than a Jade. Item.
She can milk, look you, a sweet virtue in a maid with
clean hands.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
How now Seignior Lance? what news with
your Mastership?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: With my Mastership? why, it is at Sea:

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
Well, your old vice still: mistake the word: what
news then in your paper?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: The blackest news that ever thou heardest.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Why man? how black?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why, as black as Ink.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Let me read them?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Fie on thee Iolt-head, thou canst not read.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Thou liest: I can.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I will try thee: tell me this: who begot thee?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Marry, the son of my Grandfather.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
O illiterate loiterer; it was the son of thy
Grandmother: this proves that thou canst not read.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Come fool, come: try me in thy paper.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: There: and Saint. Nicholas be thy speed.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Inprimis she can milk.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Aye that she can.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Item, she brews good Ale.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
And thereof comes the proverb: (Blessing of
your heart, you brew good Ale.)

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Item, she can sow.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: That is as much as to say (Can she so?)

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Item she can knit.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
What need a man care for a stock with a wench,
When she can knit him a stock?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Item, she can wash and scour.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
A special virtue: for then she need not be
washed, and scoured.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Item, she can spin.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
Then may I set the world on wheels, when she
can spin for her living.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Item, she hath many nameless virtues.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
That is as much as to say Bastard virtues: that
indeed know not their fathers; and therefore have no
names.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Here follow her vices.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Close at the heels of her virtues.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
Item, she is not to be fasting in respect of her
breath.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
Well: that fault may be mended with a breakfast:
read on.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Item, she hath a sweet mouth.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: That makes amends for her sour breath.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Item, she doth talk in her sleep.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
It is no matter for that; so she sleep not in her
talk.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Item, she is slow in words.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O villain, that set this down among her vices;
To be slow in words, is a woman's only virtue:
I pray thee out with it, and place it for her chief virtue.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Item, she is proud.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Out with that too:
It was Eves legacy, and cannot be ta'en from her.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Item, she hath no teeth.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I care not for that neither: because I love crusts.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Item, she is cursed.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Well: the best is, she hath no teeth to bite.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Item, she will often praise her liquor.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
If her liquor be good, she shall: if she will not,
I will; for good things should be praised.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Item, she is too liberal.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
Of her tongue she cannot; for that is writ down
she is slow of: of her purse, she shall not, for that I will
keep shut: Now, of another thing she may, and that
cannot I help. Well, proceed.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
Item, she hath more hair than wit, and more
faults than hairs, and more wealth than faults.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
Stop there: I will have her: she was mine, and not
mine, twice or thrice in that last Article: rehearse that
once more.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Item, she hath more hair than wit.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
More hair than wit: it may be I will prove it: The
cover of the salt, hides the salt, and therefore it is more
than the salt; the hair that covers the wit, is more
than the wit; for the greater hides the less: What is
next?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: And more faults than hairs.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: That is monstrous: o that that were out.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: And more wealth than faults.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
Why that word makes the faults gracious:
Well, I will have her: and if it be a match, as nothing is
impossible.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
Why then, will I tell thee, that thy Master stays
for thee at the North gate.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: For me?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
For thee? Aye, who art thou? he hath staid for a better
man than thee.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: And must I go to him?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
Thou must run to him; for thou hast staid so long,
that going will scarce serve the turn.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
Why didst not tell me sooner? pox of your love
Letters.

sp.speaker: La.
Du.
sp.l: Sir Thurio, fear not, but that she will love you
Now Valentine is banished from her sight.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Since his exile she hath despised me most,
Forsworn my company, and railed at me,
That I am desperate of obtaining her.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: This weak impress of Love, is as a figure
Trenched in ice, which with an hours heat
Dissolves to water, and doth loose his form.
A little time will melt her frozen thoughts,
And worthless Valentine shall be forgot.
How now sir Protheus, is your countryman
(According to our Proclamation) gone?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Gone, my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: My daughter takes his going grievously?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: A little time (my Lord) will kill that grief.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: So I believe: but Thurio thinks not so:
Protheus, the good conceit I hold of thee,
(For thou hast shown some sign of good desert)
Makes me the better to confer with thee.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Longer than I prove loyal to your Grace,
Let me not live, to look upon your Grace.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Thou knowest how willingly, I would effect
The match between sir Thurio, and my daughter?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I do my Lord.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: And also, I think, thou art not ignorant
How she opposes her against my will?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: She did my Lord, when Valentine was here.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Aye, and perversely, she perseveres so:
What might we do to make the girl forget
The love of Valentine, and love sir Thurio?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: The best way is, to slander Valentine,
With falsehood, cowardice, and poor descent:
Three things, that women highly hold in hate.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Aye, but she will think, that it is spoke in hate.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Aye, if his enemy deliver it.
Therefore it must with circumstance be spoken
By one, whom she esteemeth as his friend.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Then you must undertake to slander him.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: And that (my Lord) I shall be loath to do:
It is an ill office for a Gentleman,
Especially against his very friend.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Where your good word cannot advantage him,
Your slander never can endamage him;
Therefore the office is indifferent,
Being entreated to it by your friend.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: You have prevailed (my Lord) if I can do it
By aught that I can speak in his dispraise,
She shall not long continue love to him:
But say this weed her love from Valentine,
It follows not that she will love sir Thurio.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Therefore, as you unwind her love from him;
Lest it should ravel, and be good to none,
You must provide to bottom it on me:
Which must be done, by praising me as much
As you, in worth dispraise, sir Valentine.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: And Protheus, we dare trust you in this kind,
Because we know (on Valentines report)
You are already loves firm votary,
And cannot soon revolt, and change your mind.
Upon this warrant, shall you have access,
Where you, with Siluia, may confer at large.
For she is lumpish, heavy, melancholy,
And (for your friends sake) will be glad of you;
Where you may temper her, by your persuasion,
To hate young Valentine, and love my friend.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: As much as I can do, I will effect:
But you sir Thurio, are not sharp enough:
You must lay Lime, to tangle her desires
By wailful Sonnets, whose composed rhymes
Should be full fraught with serviceable vows.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Aye, much is the force of heaven-bred Poesy.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Say that upon the altar of her beauty
You sacrifice your tears, your sighs, your heart:
Write till your ink be dry: and with your tears
Moist it again: and frame some feeling line,
That may discover such integrity:
For Orpheus Lute, was strung with Poets sinews,
Whose golden touch could soften steel and stones;
Make Tigers tame, and huge Leviathans
Forsake unsounded deeps, to dance on Sands.
After your dire-lamenting Elegies,
Visit by night your Ladies chamber-window
With some sweet Consort; To their Instruments
Tune a deploring dump: the nights dead silence
Will well become such sweet complaining grievance:
This, or else nothing, will inherit her.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: This discipline, shows thou hast been in love.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: And thy advice, this night, I will put in practise:
Therefore, sweet Protheus, my direction-giver,
Let us into the City presently
To sort some Gentlemen, well skilled in Music.
I have a Sonnet, that will serve the turn
To give the onset to thy good advise.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: About it Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: We will wait upon your Grace, till after Supper,
And afterword determine our proceedings.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Even now about it, I will pardon you.

div2.head: Actus Quartus. Scoena Prima.
div2.stage: Enter Valentine, Speed, and certain Outlaws.

sp.speaker: 1.Out-l
sp.l: Fellows, stand fast: I see a passenger.

sp.speaker: 2.Out.
sp.l: If there be ten, shrink not, but down with them .

sp.speaker: 3.Out.
sp.l: Stand sir, and throw us that you have about ye.
If not: we will make you sit, and rifle you.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: Sir we are undone; these are the Villains
That all the Travellers do fear so much.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: My friends.

sp.speaker: 1.Out.
sp.l: That is not so, sir: we are your enemies.

sp.speaker: 2.Out.
sp.l: Peace: we will hear him.

sp.speaker: 3.Out.
sp.l: Aye by my beard will we: for he is a proper man.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Then know that I have little wealth to loose;
A man I am, crossed with adversity:
My riches, are these poor habiliments,
Of which, if you should here disfurnish me,
You take the sum and substance that I have.

sp.speaker: 2.Out.
sp.l: Whether travel you?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: To Verona.

sp.speaker: 1.Out.
sp.l: Whence came you?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: From Milan.

sp.speaker: 3.Out.
sp.l: Have you long sojourned there?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Some sixteen months, and longer might have staid,
If crooked fortune had not thwarted me.

sp.speaker: 1.Out.
sp.l: What, were you banished thence?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: I was.

sp.speaker: 2.Out.
sp.l: For what offence?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: For that which now torments me to rehearse;
I killed a man, whose death I much repent,
But yet I slew him manfully, in fight,
Without false vantage, or base treachery.

sp.speaker: 1.Out.
sp.l: Why never repent it, if it were done so;
But were you banished for so small a fault?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: I was, and held me glad of such a doom.

sp.speaker: 2.Out.
sp.l: Have you the Tongues?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: My youthful travail, therein made me happy,
Or else I often had been often miserable.

sp.speaker: 3.Out.
sp.l: By the bare scalp of Robin Hoods fat Fryer,
This fellow were a King, for our wild faction.

sp.speaker: 1.Out.
sp.l: We will have him: Sirs, a word.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: Master, be one of them:
It is an honourable kind of thievery.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Peace villain.

sp.speaker: 2.Out.
sp.l: Tell us this: have you anything to take to?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Nothing but my fortune.

sp.speaker: 3.Out.
sp.l: Know then, that some of us are Gentlemen,
Such as the fury of ungoverned youth
Thrust from the company of awful men.
Myself was from Verona banished,
For practising to steal away a Lady,
And heir and Niece, allied unto the Duke.

sp.speaker: 2.Out.
sp.l: And I from Mantua, for a Gentleman,
Who, in my mood, I stabbed unto the heart.

sp.speaker: 1.Out.
sp.l: And I, for suchlike petty crimes as these.
But to the purpose: for we cite our faults,
That they may hold excused our lawless lives;
And partly seeing you are beautified
With goodly shape; and by your own report,
A Linguist, and a man of such perfection,
As we do in our quality much want.

sp.speaker: 2.Out.
sp.l: Indeed because you are a banished man,
Therefore, above the rest, we parley to you:
Are you content to be our General?
To make a virtue of necessity,
And live as we do in this wilderness?

sp.speaker: 3.Out.
sp.l: What sayst thou? wilt thou be of our consort?
Say Aye, and be the captain of us all:
We will do thee homage, and be ruled by thee,
Love thee, as our Commander, and our King.

sp.speaker: 1.Out.
sp.l: But if thou scorn our courtesy, thou diest.

sp.speaker: 2.Out.
sp.l: Thou shalt not live, to brag what we have offered.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: I take your offer, and will live with you,
Provided that you do no outrages
On silly women, or poor passengers.

sp.speaker: 3.Out.
sp.l: No, we detest such vile base practises.
Come, go with us, we will bring thee to our Crews,
