And show thee all the Treasure we have got;
Which, with ourselves, all rest at thy dispose.

div2.head: Scoena Secunda.
div2.stage: Enter Protheus, Thurio, Iulia, Host, Musician, Siluia.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Already have I been false to Valentine,
And now I must be as unjust to Thurio,
Under the colour of commending him,
I have access my own love to prefer.
But Siluia is too fair, too true, too holy,
To be corrupted with my worthless gifts;
When I protest true loyalty to her,
She twits me with my falsehood to my friend;
When to her beauty I commend my vows,
She bids me think how I have been forsworn
In breaking faith with Iulia, whom I loved;
And notwithstanding all her sudden quips,
The least whereof would quell a lovers hope:
Yet (Spaniel-like) the more she spurns my love,
The more it grows, and fawneth on her still;
But here comes Thurio; now must we to her window,
And give some evening Music to her ear.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: How now, sir Protheus, are you crept before us?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Aye gentle Thurio, for you know that love
Will creep in service, where it cannot go.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Aye, but I hope, Sir, that you love not here.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Sir, but I do: or else I would be hence.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Who, Siluia?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Aye, Siluia, for your sake.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: I thank you for your own: Now Gentlemen
Let us tune: and to it lustily awhile.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Now, my young guest; methinks you are allycholly;
I pray you why is it?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Marry (mine Host) because I cannot be merry.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p:
Come, we will have you merry: I will bring you where
you shall hear Music, and see the Gentleman that
you asked for.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: But shall I hear him speak.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Aye that you shall.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: That will be Music.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Hark, hark.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Is he among these?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Aye: but peace, let us hear them.

sp.speaker: Song.

l.emph: Who is Siluia? what is she?
That all our Swains commend her?

sp.l: Holy, fair, and wise is she,
The heaven such grace did lend her,
that she might admired be.

l.emph: Is she kind as she is fair?

sp.l: Love doth to her eyes repair,

l.emph: To help him of his blindness:

sp.l: And being helped, inhabits there.
Then to Siluia, let us sing,
That Siluia is excelling;
Upon the dull earth dwelling.
To her let us Garlands bring.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: How now? are you sadder than you were before;
How do you, man? the Music likes you not.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: You mistake: the Musician likes me not.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Why, my pretty youth?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: He plays false (father.)

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: How, out of tune on the strings.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Not so: but yet
So false that he grieves my very heartstrings.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: You have a quick ear.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Aye, I would I were deaf: it makes me have a slow heart.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I perceive you delight not in Music.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Not a whit, when it jars so.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Hark, what fine change is in the Music.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Aye: that change is the spite.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: You would have them always play but one thing.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I would always have one play but one thing.
But Host, doth this Sir Protheus, that we talk on,
Often resort unto this Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I tell you what Lance his man told me,
He loved her out of all nick.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Where is Lance?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p:
Gone to seek his dog, which tomorrow, by his
Masters command, he must carry for a present to his
Lady.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Peace, stand aside, the company parts.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Sir Thurio, fear not you, I will so plead,
That you shall say, my cunning drift excels.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Where meet we?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: At Saint Gregories well.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Madam: good even to your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I thank you for your Music (Gentlemen)
Who is that that spake?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: One (Lady) if you knew his pure hearts truth,
You would quickly learn to know him by his voice.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Sir Protheus, as I take it.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Sir Protheus (gentle Lady) and your Servant.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: What is your will?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: That I may compass yours.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: You have your wish: my will is even this,
That presently you hie you home to bed:
Thou subtle, perjured, false, disloyal man:
Thinkst thou I am so shallow, so conceitless,
To be seduced by thy flattery,
That hast deceived so many with thy vows?
Return, return, and make thy love amends:
For me (by this pale queen of night I swear)
I am so far from granting thy request,
That I despise thee, for thy wrongful suite;
And by and by intend to chide myself,
Even for this time I spend in talking to thee.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I grant (sweet love) that I did love a Lady,
But she is dead.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: It were false, if I should speak it;
For I am sure she is not buried.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Say that she be: yet Valentine thy friend
Survives; to whom (thyself art witness)
I am betrothed; and art thou not ashamed
To wrong him, with thy importunacy?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I likewise hear that Valentine is dead.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: And so suppose am I; for in her grave
Assure thyself, my love is buried.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Sweet Lady, let me rake it from the earth.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Go to thy Ladies grave and call hers thence,
Or at the least, in hers, sepulchre thine.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: He heard not that.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Madam: if your heart be so obdurate:
Vouchsafe me yet your Picture for my love,
The Picture that is hanging in your chamber:
To that I will speak, to that I will sigh and weep:
For since the substance of your perfect self
Is else devoted, I am but a shadow;
And to your shadow, will I make true love.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: If it were a substance you would sure deceive it,
And make it but a shadow, as I am.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I am very loath to be your Idol Sir;
But, since your falsehood shall become you well
To worship shadows, and adore false shapes,
Send to me in the morning, and I will send it:
And so, good rest.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: As wretches have overnight
That wait for execution in the morn.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Host, will you go?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: By my Hollidame, I was fast asleep.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Pray you, where lies Sir Protheus?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Marry, at my house:
Trust me, I think it is almost day.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Not so: but it hath been the longest night
That ere I watched, and the most heaviest.

sp.speaker: Eg.
sp.l: This is the hour that Madam Siluia
Entreated me to call, and know her mind:
There is some great matter she would employ me in.
Madam, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Who calls?

sp.speaker: Eg.
sp.l: Your servant, and your friend;
One that attends your Ladyships command.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Sir Eglamore, a thousand times good morrow.

sp.speaker: Eg.
sp.l: As many (worthy Lady) to yourself:
According to your Ladyships impose,
I am thus early come, to know what service
It is your pleasure to command me in.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: O Eglamoure, thou art a Gentleman:
Think not I flatter (for I swear I do not)
Valiant, wise, remorseful, well accomplished.
Thou art not ignorant what dear good will
I bear unto the banished Valentine:
Nor how my father would enforce me marry
Vain Thurio (whom my very soul abhorred.)
Thyself hast loved, and I have heard thee say
No grief did ever come so near thy heart,
As when thy Lady, and thy true-love died,
Upon whose Grave thou vowedest pure chastity:
Sir Eglamoure: I would to Valentine
To Mantua, where I hear, he makes abode;
And for the ways are dangerous to pass,
I do desire thy worthy company,
Upon whose faith and honour, I repose.
Urge not my fathers anger (Eglamoure)
But think upon my grief (a Ladies grief)
And on the justice of my flying hence,
To keep me from a most unholy match,
Which heaven and fortune still rewards with plagues.
I do desire thee, even from a heart
As full of sorrows, as the Sea of sands,
To bear me company, and go with me:
If not, to hide what I have said to thee,
That I may venture to depart alone.

sp.speaker: Egl.
sp.l: Madam, I pity much your grievances,
Which, since I know they virtuously are placed,
I give consent to go along with you,
Wreaking as little what betideth me,
As much, I wish all good befortune you.
When will you go?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: This evening coming.

sp.speaker: Eg.
sp.l: Where shall I meet you?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: At Friar Patrickes Cell,
Where I intend holy Confession.

sp.speaker: Eg.
sp.l: I will not fail your Ladyship:
Good morrow (gentle Lady.)

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Good morrow, kind Sir Eglamoure.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p:
When a man's servant shall play the Cur with
him (look you) it goes hard: one that I brought up of
a puppy: one that I saved from drowning, when three or
four of his blind brothers and sisters went to it: I have
taught him (even as one would say precisely, thus I
would teach a dog) I was sent to deliver him, as a present
to Mistress Siluia, from my Master; and I came no
sooner into the dining chamber, but he steps me to her
Trencher, and steals her Capons-leg: O, it is a foul
thing, when a Cur cannot keep himself in all companies:
I would have (as one should say) one that takes upon
him to be a dog indeed, to be, as it were, a dog at all
things. If I had not had more wit than he, to take a fault
upon me that he did, I think verily he had been hanged
for it: sure as I live he had suffered for it: you shall judge:
He thrusts me himself into the company of three or
four gentleman-like dogs, under the Dukes table: he
had not been there (bless the mark) a pissing while, but
all the chamber smelt him: out with the dog (says one)
what cur is that (says another) whip him out (says the
third) hang him up (says the Duke.) I having been acquainted
with the smell before, knew it was Crab; and
goes me to the fellow that whips the dogs: friend
(quoth I) you mean to whip the dog: Aye marry do I
(quoth he) you do him the more wrong (quoth I) it was
I did the thing you wot of: he makes me no more ado,
but whips me out of the chamber: how many Masters
would do this for his Servant? nay, I will be sworn I have
sat in the stocks, for puddings he hath stolen, otherwise
he had been executed: I have stood on the Pillory for
Geese he hath killed, otherwise he had suffered for it: thou
thinkst not of this now: nay, I remember the trick you
served me, when I took my leave of Madam Siluia: did
not I bid thee still mark me, and do as I do; when didst
thou see me heave up my leg, and make water against a
Gentlewoman's farthingale? didst thou ever see me do
such a trick?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Sebastian is thy name: I like thee well,
And will employ thee in some service presently.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: In what you please, I will do what I can.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I hope thou wilt.
How now you whoreson peasant,
Where have you been these two days loitering?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
Marry Sir, I carried Mistress Siluia the dog you
bad me.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: And what says she to my little Jewel?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
Marry she says your dog was a cur, and tells you
currish thanks is good enough for such a present.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: But she received my dog?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: No indeed did she not:
Here have I brought him back again.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: What, didst thou offer her this from me?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Aye Sir, the other Squirrel was stolen from me
By the Hangman's boys in the market place,
And then I offered her mine own, who is a dog
As big as ten of yours, and therefore the gift the greater.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Go, get thee hence, and find my dog again,
Or never return again into my sight.
Away, I say: stayest thou to vex me here;
A Slave, that still on end, turns me to shame:
Sebastian, I have entertained thee,
Partly that I have need of such a youth,
That can with some discretion do my business:
For it is no trusting to yond foolish Lout;
But chiefly, for thy face, and thy behaviour,
Which (if my Augury deceive me not)
Witness good bringing up, fortune, and truth:
Therefore know thee, for this I entertain thee.
Go presently, and take this Ring with thee,
Deliver it to Madam Siluia;
She loved me well, delivered it to me.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: It seems you loved not her, not leave her token:
She is dead belike?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Not so: I think she lives.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Alas.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Why dost thou cry alas?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I cannot choose but pity her.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Wherefore shouldest thou pity her?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Because, methinks that she loved you as well
As you do love your Lady Siluia:
She dreams on him, that has forgot her love,
You dote on her, that cares not for your love.
It is pity Love, should be so contrary:
And thinking on it, makes me cry alas.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Well: give her that Ring, and therewithal
This Letter: that is her chamber: Tell my Lady,
I claim the promise for her heavenly Picture:
Your message done, hie home unto my chamber,
Where thou shalt find me sad, and solitary.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: How many women would do such a message?
Alas poor Protheus, thou hast entertained
A Fox, to be the shepherd of thy Lambs;
Alas, poor fool, why do I pity him
That with his very heart despiseth me?
Because he loves her, he despiseth me,
Because I love him, I must pity him.
This Ring I gave him, when he parted from me,
To bind him to remember my good will:
And now am I (unhappy Messenger)
To plead for that, which I would not obtain;
To carry that, which I would have refused;
To praise his faith, which I would have dispraised.
I am my Masters true confirmed Love,
But cannot be true servant to my Master,
Unless I prove false traitor to myself.
Yet will I woe for him, but yet so coldly,
As (heaven it knows) I would not have him speed.
Gentlewoman, good day: I pray you be my mean
To bring me where to speak with Madam Siluia.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: What would you with her, if that I be she?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: If you be she, I do entreat your patience
To hear me speak the message I am sent on.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: From whom?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: From my Master, Sir Protheus, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: O: he sends you for a Picture?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Aye, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Vrsula, bring my Picture there,
Go, give your Master this: tell him from me,
One Iulia, that his changing thoughts forget
Would better fit his Chamber, than this Shadow.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Madam, please you peruse this Letter;
Pardon me (Madam) I have unadvised
Delivered you a paper that I should not;
This is the Letter to your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I pray thee let me look on that again.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: It may not be: good Madam pardon me.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: There, hold:
I will not look upon your Masters lines:
I know they are stuffed with protestations,
And full of new-found oaths, which he will break
As easily, as I do tear his paper.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Madam, he sends your Ladyship this Ring.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: The more shame for him, that he sends it me;
For I have heard him say a thousand times,
His Iulia gave it him, at his departure:
Though his false finger have profaned the Ring,
Mine shall not do his Iulia so much wrong.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: She thanks you.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: What sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I thank you Madam, that you tender her:
Poor Gentlewoman, my Master wrongs her much.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Dost thou know her?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Almost as well as I do know myself.
To think upon her woes, I do protest
That I have wept a hundred several times.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Belike she thinks that Protheus hath forsook her?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I think she doth: and that is her cause of sorrow.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Is she not passing fair?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: She hath been fairer (Madam) than she is,
When she did think my Master loved her well;
She, in my judgment, was as fair as you.
But since she did neglect her looking-glass,
And threw her Sun-expelling Mask away,
The air hath starved the roses in her cheeks,
And pinched the lily tincture of her face,
That now she is become as black as I.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: How tall was she?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: About my stature: for at Pentecost,
When all our Pageants of delight were played,
Our youth got me to play the woman's part,
And I was trimmed in Madam Iulias gown,
Which served me as fit, by all men's judgments,
As if the garment had been made for me:
Therefore I know she is about my height,
And at that time I made her weep a good,
For I did play a lamentable part.
(Madam) it was Ariadne, passioning
For Thesus perjury, and unjust flight;
Which I so lively acted with my tears:
That my poor Mistress moved therewithal,
Wept bitterly: and would I might be dead,
If I in thought felt not her very sorrow.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: She is beholding to thee (gentle youth)
Alas (poor Lady) desolate, and left;
I weep myself to think upon thy words:
Here youth: there is my purse; I give thee this
For thy sweet Mistress sake, because thou lovest her. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: And she shall thank you for it, if ere you know her.
A virtuous gentlewoman, mild, and beautiful.
I hope my Masters suit will be but cold,
Since she respects my Mistress love so much.
Alas, how love can trifle with itself:
Here is her Picture: let me see, I think
If I had such Attire, this face of mine
Were full as lovely, as is this of hers;
And yet the Painter flattered her a little,
Unless I flatter with myself too much.
Her hair is Auburn, mine is perfect Yellow;
If that be all the difference in his love,
I will get me such a coloured Periwig:
Her eyes are grey as glass, and so are mine.
Aye, but her forehead is low, and mine is as high:
What should it be that he respects in her,
But I can make respective in myself?
If this fond Love, were not a blinded god.
Come shadow, come, and take this shadow up,
For it is thy rival: O thou senseless form,
Thou shalt be worshipped, kissed, loved, and adored;
And were there sense in his Idolatry,
My substance should be statue in thy stead.
I will use thee kindly, for thy Mistress sake
That used me so: or else by Jove, I vow,
I should have scratched out your unseeing eyes,
To make my Master out of love with thee.

sp.speaker: Egl.
sp.l: The Sun begins to guild the western sky,
And now it is about the very hour
That Siluia, at Fryer Patricks Cell should meet me,
She will not fail; for Lovers break not hours,
Unless it be to come before their time,
So much they spur their expedition.
See where she comes: Lady a happy evening.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Amen, Amen: go on (good Eglamoure)
Out at the Postern by the Abbey wall;
I fear I am attended by some Spies.

sp.speaker: Egl.
sp.l: Fear not: the Forest is not three leagues off,
If we recover that, we are sure enough.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Sir Protheus, what says Siluia to my suit?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: O Sir, I find her milder than she was,
And yet she takes exceptions at your person.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: What? that my leg is too long?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: No, that it is too little.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: I will wear a Boot, to make it somewhat rounder.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: But love will not be spurred to what it loathes.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: What says she to my face?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: She says it is a fair one.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: Nay then the wanton lies: my face is black.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: But Pearls are fair; and the old saying is,
Black men are Pearls, in beauteous Ladies eyes.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: It is true, such Pearls as put out Ladies eyes,
For I had rather wink, than look on them.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: How likes she my discourse?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Ill, when you talk of war.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: But well, when I discourse of love and peace.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: But better indeed, when you hold you peace.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: What says she to my valour?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: O Sir, she makes no doubt of that.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: She needs not, when she knows it cowardice.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: What says she to my birth?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: That you are well derived.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: True: from a Gentleman, to a fool.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: Considers she my Possessions?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: O, Aye: and pities them.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: Wherefore?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: That such an Ass should owe them.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: That they are out by Lease.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Here comes the Duke.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How now sir Protheus; how now Thurio?
Which of you saw Eglamoure of late?

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Saw you my daughter?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Neither.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Why then
She is fled unto that peasant, Valentine;
And Eglamoure is in her Company:
It is true: for Friar Laurence met them both
As he, in penance wandered through the Forest:
Him he knew well: and guessed that it was she,
But being masked, he was not sure of it.
Besides she did intend Confession
At Patricks Cell this even, and there she was not.
These likelihoods confirm her flight from hence;
Therefore I pray you stand, not to discourse,
But mount you presently, and meet with me
Upon the rising of the Mountain foot
That leads toward Mantua, whether they are fled:
Dispatch (sweet Gentlemen) and follow me.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: Why this it is, to be a peevish Girl,
That flies her fortune when it follows her:
I will after; more to be revenged on Eglamoure,
Than for the love of reckless Siluia.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: And I will follow, more for Siluias love
Than hate of Eglamoure that goes with her.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: And I will follow, more to cross that love
Than hate for Siluia, that is gone for love.

sp.speaker: 1.Out.
sp.l: Come, come be patient:
We must bring you to our Captain.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: A thousand more mischances than this one
Have learned me how to brooke this patiently.

sp.speaker: 2 Out.
sp.l: Come, bring her away.

sp.speaker: 1 Out.
sp.l: Where is the Gentleman that was with her?

sp.speaker: 3 Out.
sp.l: Being nimble footed, he hath outrun us.
But Moyses and Valerius follow him:
Go thou with her to the West end of the wood,
There is our Captain: We will follow him that is fled,
The Thicket is beset, he cannot scape.

sp.speaker: 1 Out.
sp.l: Come, I must bring you to our Captains cave.
Fear not: he bears an honourable mind,
And will not use a woman lawlessly.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: O Valentine: this I endure for thee.

div2.head: Scoena Quarta.
div2.stage:
Enter Valentine, Protheus, Siluia, Iulia, Duke, Thurio,
Outlaws.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: How use doth breed a habit in a man?
This shadowy desert, unfrequented woods
I better brooke than flourishing peopled Towns:
Here can I sit alone, unseen of any,
And to the Nightingales complaining Notes
Tune my distresses, and record my woes.
O thou that dost inhabit in my breast,
Leave not the Mansion so long Tenant-less,
Lest growing ruinous, the building fall,
And leave no memory of what it was,
Repair me, with thy presence, Siluia:
Thou gentle Nymph, cherish thy forlorn swain.
What hallowing, and what stir is this today?
These are my mates, that make their wills their Law,
Have some unhappy passenger in chase;
They love me well: yet I have much to do
To keep them from uncivil outrages.
Withdraw thee Valentine: who is this comes here?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Madam, this service I have done for you
(Though you respect not aught your servant doth)
To hazard life, and rescue you from him,
That would have forced your honour, and your love,
Vouchsafe me for my meed, but one fair look:
(A smaller boon than this I cannot beg,
And less than this, I am sure you cannot give.)

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: How like a dream is this? I see, and hear:
Love, lend me patience to forbear awhile.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: O miserable, unhappy that I am.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Unhappy were you (Madam) ere I came:
But by my coming, I have made you happy.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: By thy approach thou makest me most unhappy.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: And me, when he approacheth to your presence.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Had I been seized by a hungry Lion,
I would have been a breakfast to the Beast,
Rather than have false Protheus rescue me:
O heaven be judge how I love Valentine,
Whose life is as tender to me as my soul,
And full as much (for more there cannot be)
I do detest false perjured Protheus:
Therefore be gone, solicit me no more.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: What dangerous action, stood it next to death
Would I not undergo, for one calm look:
O it is the curse in Love, and still approved
When women cannot love, where they are beloved.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: When Protheus cannot love, where he is beloved:
Read over Iulia's heart, (thy first best Love)
For whose dear sake, thou didst then rend thy faith
Into a thousand oaths; and all those oaths,
Descended into perjury, to love me,
Thou hast no faith left now, unless thou hadst two,
And that is far worse than none: better have none
Than plural faith, which is too much by one:
Thou Counterfeit, to thy true friend.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: In Love,
Who respects friend?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: All men but Protheus.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Nay, if the gentle spirit of moving words
Can no way change you to a milder form;
I will woo you like a Soldier, at arms end,
And love you against the nature of Love: force ye.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: O heaven.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I will force thee yield to my desire.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Ruffian: let go that rude uncivil touch,
Thou friend of an ill fashion.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Valentine.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Thou common friend, that is without faith or love,
For such is a friend now: treacherous man,
Thou hast beguiled my hopes; nought but mine eye
Could have persuaded me: now I dare not say
I have one friend alive; thou wouldst disprove me:
Who should be trusted, when ones right hand
Is perjured to the bosom? Protheus
I am sorry I must never trust thee more,
But count the world a stranger for thy sake:
The private wound is deepest: o time, most accursed.
Amongst all foes that a friend should be the worst?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: My shame and guilt confounds me:
Forgive me Valentine: if hearty sorrow
Be a sufficient Ransom for offence,
I tender it here: I do as truly suffer,
As ere I did commit.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Then I am paid:
And once again, I do receive thee honest;
Who by Repentance is not satisfied,
Is nor of heaven, nor earth; for these are pleased:
By Penitence the Eternals wrath is appeased:
And that my love may appear plain and free,
All that was mine, in Siluia, I give thee.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: O me unhappy.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Look to the Boy.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Why, Boy?
Why wag: how now? what is the matter? look up: speak.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p:
O good sir, my master charged me to deliver a ring
to Madam Siluia: which (out of my neglect) was never done.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Where is that ring? boy?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Here it is: this is it.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: How? let me see.
Why this is the ring I gave to Iulia.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: O, cry you mercy sir, I have mistook:
This is the ring you sent to Siluia.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: But how camest thou by this ring? at my depart
I gave this unto Iulia.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: And Iulia herself did give it me,
And Iulia herself hath brought it hither.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: How? Iulia?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Behold her, that gave aim to all thy oaths,
And entertained them deeply in her heart.
How oft hast thou with perjury cleft the root?
O Protheus, let this habit make thee blush.
Be thou ashamed that I have took upon me,
Such an immodest raiment; if shame live
In a disguise of love?
It is the lesser blot modesty finds,
Women to change their shapes, than men their minds.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Than men their minds? it is true: o heaven, were man
But Constant, he were perfect; that one error
Fills him with faults: makes him run through all the sins;
Inconstancy falls off, ere it begins:
What is in Siluia's face, but I may spy
More fresh in Iulia's, with a constant eye?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Come, come: a hand from either:
Let me be blessed to make this happy close:
It were pity two such friends should be long foes.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Bear witness (heaven) I have my wish forever.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: And I mine.

sp.speaker: Out-l.
sp.l: A prize: a prize: a prize.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Forbear, forbear I say: It is my Lord the Duke.
Your Grace is welcome to a man disgraced,
Banished Valentine.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Sir Valentine?

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: Yonder is Siluia: and Siluia is mine.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Thurio give back; or else embrace thy death:
Come not within the measure of my wrath:
Do not name Siluia thine: if once again,
Verona shall not hold thee: here she stands,
Take but possession of her, with a Touch:
I dare thee, but to breath upon my Love.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.l: Sir Valentine, I care not for her, I:
I hold him but a fool that will endanger
His Body, for a Girl that loves him not:
I claim her not, and therefore she is thine.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: The more degenerate and base art thou
To make such means for her, as thou hast done,
And leave her on such slight conditions.
Now, by the honour of my Ancestry,
I do applaud thy spirit, Valentine,
And think thee worthy of an Empress love:
Know then, I here forget all former griefs,
Cancel all grudge, repeal thee home again,
Plead a new state in thy unrivalled merit,
To which I thus subscribe: Sir Valentine,
Thou art a Gentleman, and well derived,
Take thou thy Siluia, for thou hast deserved her.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: I thank your Grace, your gift hath made me happy:
I now beseech you (for your daughters sake)
To grant one Boon that I shall ask of you.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I grant it (for thine own) whatever it be.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: These banished men, that I have kept withal,
Are men endued with worthy qualities:
Forgive them what they have committed here,
And let them be recalled from their Exile:
They are reformed, civil, full of good,
And fit for great employment (worthy Lord.)

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Thou hast prevailed, I pardon them and thee:
Dispose of them, as thou knowest their deserts.
Come, let us go, we will include all jars,
With Triumphs, Mirth, and rare solemnity.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: And as we walk along, I dare be bold
With our discourse, to make your Grace to smile.
What think you of this Page (my Lord?)

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I think the Boy hath grace in him, he blushes.

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: I warrant you (my Lord) more grace, than Boy.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What mean you by that saying?

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: Please you, I will tell you, as we pass along,
That you will wonder what hath fortuned:
Come Protheus, it is your penance, but to hear
The story of your Loves discovered.
That done, our day of marriage shall be yours,
One Feast, one house, one mutual happiness.
